title: Implied Volatility Rank (IVR)
badge_description: You know how to identify cheap vs expensive options using context

screens.headline: Is 50% IV high or low?
screens.text: DEPENDS ON THE STOCK. TSLA at 50% IV is actually LOW. AAPL at 50% IV is SKY HIGH. IVR gives you context - the secret to not overpaying for options.

screens.headline: IVR: Context is Everything
screens.text: Implied Volatility Rank shows where CURRENT IV sits relative to its 52-week range. IVR 100% = IV at 52-week high (very expensive). IVR 0% = IV at 52-week low (very cheap). Formula: (Current IV - 52w Low) / (52w High - 52w Low) Ã— 100

screens.headline: IVR is Like Temperature Context
screens.text: 75Â°F is hot in Alaska but cool in Arizona. Same number, different context. IV 60% is low for TSLA but high for KO. IVR tells you if it's hot or cold FOR THAT STOCK.

reveal_sections.label: Stock A: IV 80%, IVR 20% = CHEAP for this stock
Stock B: IV 30%, IVR 90% = EXPENSIVE for this stock
Always check IVR, not just raw IV number
IVR > 50% = Consider selling. IVR < 30% = Consider buying

cards.definition: IV in top half of range = relatively expensive options
cards.example: Good time to SELL premium (covered calls, CSPs, spreads)

cards.definition: IV in bottom third of range = relatively cheap options
cards.example: Good time to BUY options (long calls/puts, debit spreads)

cards.definition: Neutral zone - no strong IV edge either way
cards.example: Use directional strategies, not premium collection

screens.question: Stock A has IV 40%, 52w range 20-60%. What's the IVR?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! (40 - 20) / (60 - 20) = 20/40 = 0.50 = 50% IVR. IV is exactly in the middle of its range - neutral pricing.
screens.explanation_wrong: Formula: (Current - Low) / (High - Low). So (40-20) / (60-20) = 20/40 = 50%. IVR gives you context!

screens.question: You want to sell covered calls. Which stock should you choose?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! When SELLING, you want HIGH IVR (expensive options = collect more premium). Stock C at IVR 95% means you're selling at near-peak prices. Maximum premium collection!
screens.explanation_wrong: You're SELLING options. You want to sell when prices are HIGH. IVR 95% = options are at 95th percentile = most expensive = best time to sell!

teaching_points: AAPL 35% IV looks low, but IVR 67% = actually expensive
TSLA 65% IV looks high, but IVR 31% = actually cheap!
Never judge by raw IV number alone

cards.back: Shows where current IV sits in its 52-week range. IVR 80% = IV is at 80th percentile = expensive options.
IVR > 50% = sell options. IVR < 30% = buy options. IVR 30-50% = neutral zone.
Context matters! IV 60% might be cheap for TSLA but expensive for KO. IVR adjusts for each stock's normal range.
